item.title: Talks
item.description: Resurrecting Ancient Proteins in Python | SciPy 2018 How Jupyter Makes Experimental and Computational Collaborations Easy | JupyterCon 2017

item.title: Writing your own flavor of Pandas
item.description: Pandas is Python’s DataFrame library. There are many reasons why should be using DataFrame’s in your data science workflow, but I’ll have to leave that for another post. Here, I’ll show you how to tailor Pandas to your business, research, or personal workflow using Pandas’ extension API. In versions 0.24.x, Pandas introduced a new API for extending Pandas. This API handled the boilerplate code for registering custom accessors onto Pandas objects.

item.title: Should Jupyter Notebooks go away?
Jupyter Team Meeting 2019
item.description: “If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together.” A few weeks ago, I had the opportunity to join many members of the Project Jupyter’s core development team in Washington DC for our annual team meeting. A huge thank you to Dr. Lorena Barba for hosting our team at George Washington University for the week. This was an incredible experience. I counted ~20 core contributors representing 9 different countries in the room.

item.title: Hello, world.
item.description: Finally starting a blog. Thank you to Leticia Portella and Saul Shanabrook for pushing to make it happened. I’m planning to use this site to share three major types of content. I’ll announce software that I’ve published or review software someone else published. I’ll highlight things I come across in basic science and research domains. Since my background is in science, I’ll use this blog to stay connected to that community.
